eventData.headline: BMU General Meeting / Prefrosh Introduction
eventData.description:
Prefrosh! Join us on 4/19/21 from 7:45-9:15p EST to meet the men of Yale's Black Men Union, and to participate in a general meeting. We'll introduce everyone, have a great discussion, and make sure that you leave with any questions you have answered. It's a great opportunity to connect with us as people, and to get a feel for BMU as an organization.

https://yale.zoom.us/j/93099910321?pwd=OUZIcHRMNDBFQnIvRXNNRCtCSStUUT09 (Password: BMU)

eventType.description: These events are created in coordination with the cultural centers and student groups that operate within them.

eventData.headline: La Casa's "Learning Latinx" Discussion
eventData.description:
As a preview to both formal and informal conversations that often take place at La Casa, join us for this discussion on “what does it mean to be a Latinx student?” and students’ perspectives on education. This event will highlight some of the issues unique to Latinx students through a novel short story. We’ll discuss how these two Latinx scholars grapple with the tensions of bilingualism, family life, and alienation as they navigate through the American education system.

https://yale.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_8NvaOiFeQHaQuHA2S9wEAQ

eventType.name: Master Classes
eventType.description: An opportunity to learn and experience a class from one of Yale's notable professors.

eventData.headline: Laurie Santos: The Science of Well-Being
eventData.description:
Laurie Santos is Professor of Psychology and the Director of Yale’s Comparative Cognition Lab and Canine Cognition Center. Her research connects evolutionary biology, developmental psychology, and cognitive neuroscience, exploring the evolutionary origins of the human mind by comparing the cognitive abilities of human and non-human organisms. She recently received the American Psychological Association Distinguished Scientific Award for early career contributions to Psychology, and was voted one of TIME Magazine’s “leading campus celebrities.” Her introductory-level Psychology course, “Psychology and the Good Life,” is the most popular class in Yale's history. She currently serves as the Head of Silliman College.

A zoom link for this event will be posted an hour prior to the start time.

eventType.name: Master Classes
eventType.description: An opportunity to learn and experience a class from one of Yale's notable professors.

eventData.headline: Daniel Martinez HoSang: Race, Politics, and the Law
eventData.description:
Daniel Martinez HoSang is an Associate Professor of Ethnicity Race and Migration and American Studies and holds a secondary appointment in the Department of Political Science and serves on the Education Studies Advisory Committee. His forthcoming books include A Wider Type of Freedom: How Struggles for Racial Justice Liberate Everyone (University of California Press, fall 2021); Under the Blacklight: The Intersectional Vulnerabilities that Covid Lays Bare (Haymarket Press, Spring 2021, co-edited with Kimberele Crenshaw). HoSang is the co-author (with Joseph Lowndes) of Producers, Parasites, Patriots: Race and the New Right-Wing Politics of Precarity (University of Minnesota Press, 2019) and the author of the author of Racial Propositions: Ballot Initiatives and the Making of Postwar California (University of California Press, 2010) which was awarded the 2011 James A Rawley Prize from the Organization of American Historians. He is the co-editor of three volumes: Seeing Race Again: Countering Colorblindness Across the Disciplines (with Kimberle Crenshaw, Luke Harris and George Lipsitz) University of California Press, 2019; Relational Formations of Race: Theory, Method and Practice (co-edited with Ramon Gutiérrez and Natalia Molina), University of California Press, 2019; and Racial Formation in the 21st Century (with Oneka LaBennett and Laura Pulido) University of California Press, 2012).

HoSang supports a summer community organizing training program for undergraduate students in conjunction with the Alliance for a Just Society, and a research and advocacy project on Public Reconstruction and organizing campaigns for public goods. He has a long record of collaboration with community-based organizations and labor unions as a trainer, board member, and advisor with groups including the Restaurant Opportunities Center (ROC), the Alliance for a Just Society, Oakland Kids First!, the Partnership for Safety and Justice, and Forward Together. He is a board member of the African American Policy Forum and the Connecticut Bail Fund. Through the Yale-New Haven Teachers Institute, he has taught seminars for K-12 public school teachers on Anti-racist Curriculum and Pedagogy, and works with teachers and youth organizing groups in Connecticut on teaching about racism and racial justice in the K-12 curriculum through the Anti-Racist Teaching & Learning Collective.

A zoom link for this event will be posted an hour prior to the start time.

eventType.name: Panels
eventType.description: Opportunities to hear from more than one Yale affiliate on a slew of different topics and ask questions.

eventData.headline: Multidisciplinary Academic Programs Panel
eventData.description:
To enrich the curricular opportunities available to students and faculty, the Yale College Faculty authorized the creation of multidisciplinary academic programs in the Yale College and a framework for approving them. These programs provide opportunities for Yale College students to examine pressing social challenges from a variety of disciplinary perspectives among a community of students and faculty who have shared interests. Students from any major can apply to these programs, and faculty from across the university participate in them.

Each program focuses centrally on a distinct and different set of issues, but they all share common features, including a core curriculum—beginning with a gateway course and culminating in a senior capstone project—and opportunities for practical experience that allow students to combine theory and practice, applying what they have learned in the classroom and in their research. Education Studies, Energy Studies, Global Health Studies, and Human Rights Studies are the current multidisciplinary academic programs offered in Yale College.

Learn more about them during this panel!

A zoom link for this event will be posted an hour prior to the start time.

eventData.headline: Asian American History at Yale with the AASA
eventData.description:
Come to AASA's Asian American History at Yale workshop! We will interrogate the history that Asian students have on Yale's campus, focusing on Asian-Black solidarity at the Black Panther trials, Asian students' fight for a cultural center, and the advocacy behind creating ethnic studies at Yale. This is an amazing way to understand what it means to be an Asian student at Yale, and learn a little bit about our shared histories.

http://tinyurl.com/AASAZOOM

eventType.name: Academic Departments & Programs
eventType.description: Get to know more about some academic departments & programs at Yale through these live events.

eventData.headline: Yale Library Ask Me Anything
eventData.description:
Ask Me Anything: Get to Know the Yale Library. Come learn about Yale’s library system, and the role it plays in the lives of Yale students. Bring your questions about the best study spaces, Yale’s unusual collections, getting a job in the library, and finding out about your personal librarians.

Newly admitted students are welcome to contact emily.horning@yale.edu with questions.

https://yalelibrary.zoom.us/j/96213133427

eventType.name: Student Groups
eventType.description: Opportunities to get to know student groups and resources on campus!

eventData.headline: Yale Bands Information Meeting
eventData.description:
The Department of Bands is the umbrella organization for the university’s three official bands – the Yale Concert Band, the Yale Jazz Ensemble, and the Yale Precision Marching Band. If you’re interested in joining one (or two, or all three), please attend this short meeting hosted by Director Thomas C. Duffy. Learn about all three groups, meet current members, and ask any questions you may have. Hope to see you!

Join from PC, Mac, Linux, iOS or Android: https://yale.zoom.us/j/95563246384
Or Telephone:203-432-9666 (2-ZOOM if on-campus) or 646 568 7788
Meeting ID: 955 6324 6384
International numbers available: https://yale.zoom.us/u/amdA21k0a
